info.title: PostgreSQLManagementClient
info.description: The Azure Database for PostgreSQL management API provides create, read, update, and delete functionality for Azure PostgreSQL resources including servers, databases, firewall rules, network configuration, security alert policies, log files and configurations with new business model.

role.description: Role of the server in a replication set.

capacity.description: Maximum number of read replicas allowed for a server.

values.description: Read replica is fully synchronized and actively replicating data from the primary server.
Read replica is behind the primary server and is currently catching up with pending changes.

replicationState.description: Indicates the replication state of a read replica. This property is returned only when the target server is a read replica. Possible  values are Active, Broken, Catchup, Provisioning, Reconfiguring, and Updating

promoteMode.description: Type of operation to apply on the read replica. This property is write only. Standalone means that the read replica will be promoted to a standalone server, and will become a completely independent entity from the replication set. Switchover means that the read replica will roles with the primary server.

values.description: Read replica will become an independent server.
Read replica will swap roles with primary server.

promoteOption.description: Data synchronization option to use when processing the operation specified in the promoteMode property. This property is write only.

values.description: The operation will wait for data in the read replica to be fully synchronized with its source server, before it initiates the operation.
The operation will not wait for data in the read replica to be synchronized with its source server, before it initiates the operation.

administratorLogin.description: Name of the login designated as the first password based administrator assigned to your instance of PostgreSQL. Must be specified the first time that you enable password based authentication on a server. Once set to a given value, it cannot be changed for the rest of the life of a server. If you disable password based authentication on a server which had it enabled, this password based role isn't deleted.

administratorLoginPassword.description: Password assigned to the administrator login. As long as password authentication is enabled, this password can be changed at any time.

values.description: Server is healthy and not undergoing any operations at the management or control plane level. This doesn't mean that the server is fully operational at the data plane level.
Server is being deleted.

Server is disabled. Typical reasons include: the subscription on which the server is deployed is explicitly disabled or canceled by the administrator, the spending limit has been reached, or the bill is past due. May also happen when the server is being moved to another resource group or subscription.
PostgreSQL database engine is being restarted.

Compute resources associated with the server are being stopped and deallocated. If the server has high availability enabled, the compute resources of the standby server are also stopped and deallocated.
Compute resources associated with the server are being stopped and deallocated.

Server is undergoing some changes which may or may not impact the availability of the PostgreSQL database engine. For example, the compute resources of the server are being scaled up or down, which may cause temporary unavailability of the database engine. Or, for example, a firewall rule is being added or removed, which doesn't cause any unavailability of the database engine.
PostgreSQL database engine is being restarted.
Server isn't accessible, because the key provided to encrypt and decrypt the data is in invalid state.
Server is in the process of being created.

values.description: If the operation is triggered on a non-existing server, it's equivalent to 'Create'. If the operation is triggered on an existing server, it's equivalent to 'Update'.
Operation creates a new server.
Operation updates an existing server.
Operation restores an existing backup of an existing server. This operation creates a new server, and then restores on it the backup of an existing server at a specific point in time.

Operation restores an existing backup of an existing server, on the paired region of the existing server. This operation creates a new server on the paired region of the existing server, and then restores on it the backup of an existing server at a specific point in time, in a different region. This operation is only supported on existing servers that were created with geographically redundant backups enabled.

Operation creates a replica of an existing server. This operation creates a new server, restores a base backup of the existing server (referred to as primary), and configures physical replication to asynchronously stream all changes which are recorded in the transaction log of the primary.
Operation creates a new server, initialized with the backup of a server that was recently deleted.

restartWithFailover.description: Indicates if restart the PostgreSQL database engine should failover or switch over from primary to standby. This only works if server has high availability enabled.

values.description: Triggers a failover from primary to standby without killing the primary database process first. This is a graceful failover that attempts to preserve data consistency.
Kills the primary database process first, then triggers the failover. This is more aggressive and used when the primary is unresponsive or in an unhealthy state.
Similar to 'PlannedFailover' but prefers a switch over operation where roles are swapped between primary and standby.
Kills the primary database process and then triggers a switch over with role swapping.
